repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem: there is no simple way to retrieve various pieces of information
for a bug report.

Solution: add a bug report section to checkhealth in vim.health

close https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/31847

comment_data.body: just call a runtime file, don't inline it
? `vim.version`
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,126 @@
+local M = {}
+
+local function detect_terminal()
+  if vim.env.TERM_PROGRAM then
+    local version = vim.env.TERM_PROGRAM_VERSION or ''
+    return vim.env.TERM_PROGRAM .. (version ~= '' and ' ' .. version or '')
+  end
+
+  if vim.env.KITTY_WINDOW_ID then
+    local result = vim.system({ 'kitty', '--version' }, { text = true }):wait()
+    if result.code == 0 then
+      local v = vim.version.parse(result.stdout, { strict = false })
+      return v and ('kitty ' .. tostring(v)) or 'kitty'
+    end
+    return 'kitty'
+  end
+
+  if vim.env.ALACRITTY_SOCKET or vim.env.ALACRITTY_LOG then
+    local result = vim.system({ 'alacritty', '--version' }, { text = true }):wait()
+    if result.code == 0 then
+      local v = vim.version.parse(result.stdout, { strict = false })
+      return v and ('alacritty ' .. tostring(v)) or 'alacritty'
+    end
+    return 'alacritty'
+  end
+
+  if vim.env.WEZTERM_EXECUTABLE then
+    local result = vim.system({ 'wezterm', '--version' }, { text = true }):wait()
+    if result.code == 0 then
+      local v = vim.version.parse(result.stdout, { strict = false })
+      return v and ('wezterm ' .. tostring(v)) or 'wezterm'
+    end
+    return 'wezterm'
+  end
+
+  if vim.env.KONSOLE_VERSION then
+    return 'konsole ' .. vim.env.KONSOLE_VERSION
+  end
+
+  if vim.env.VTE_VERSION then
+    return 'vte ' .. vim.env.VTE_VERSION
+  end
+
+  return 'unknown'
+end
+
+function M.check()
+  vim.health.start('Bug Report Information')
+
+  local version_output = vim.api.nvim_exec2('version', { output = true }).output
+  local nvim_version = version_output:match('NVIM v[^\n]+') or 'unknown'

+  local os_info = vim.uv.os_uname()
+  local os_string = os_info.sysname .. ' ' .. os_info.release
+  local terminal = detect_terminal()
+  local term_env = vim.env.TERM or 'unknown'
+
+  vim.health.info('Nvim version: ' .. nvim_version)

+    os_string,
+    terminal,
+    term_env
+  )
+
+  local encoded_body = vim.uri_encode(body) --- @type string
+  local issue_url = 'https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/new?labels=bug&body=' .. encoded_body
+
+  vim.health.info('')
+  local text = 'Press gx to create bug report'
+  vim.health.info(text)
+
+  vim.schedule(function()
+    local bufnr = vim.api.nvim_get_current_buf()
+    local ns = vim.api.nvim_create_namespace('bugreport')
+    local line_count = vim.api.nvim_buf_line_count(bufnr)
+
+    vim.api.nvim_buf_set_extmark(bufnr, ns, line_count - 2, 2, {
+      end_col = #text + 2,
+      url = issue_url,
+      hl_group = 'Underlined',
+    })

comment_data.body:
Rather than add a new module , just add to the existing `vim.health`  section, in `runtime/lua/vim/health/health.lua`

this "system info" can just always display in the `vim.health` section, with a "do [something] to create a bug report" info message in that section.
dedupe this logic

comment_data.body:
It's reported as `build` field:

```
:lua =vim.version()
{
  build = "ge0308dc14730",
  major = 0,
  ...
}
```

btw while we're doing this, would be very nice for the bug report to replace the `g` at start of the version with a space char, so that it auto-hyperlinks in github.

comment_data.body:
As always, we want to "namespace" anything in a global scope.
```suggestion
    _G._nvim_health_bugreport_open = function()
```

Should probably do something like `_G._... = nil` on BufDelete.

+local function check_sysinfo()
+  vim.health.start('System Info')
+
+  -- Use :version because vim.version().build returns "Homebrew" for brew installs.
+  local version_output = vim.api.nvim_exec2('version', { output = true }).output
+  local nvim_version = version_output:match('NVIM v[^\n]+') or 'unknown'
+  local commit_hash = nvim_version:match('%+g?(%x+)')
+  local version_for_report = nvim_version
+  if commit_hash then
+    version_for_report = nvim_version:gsub('%+g' .. commit_hash, ' neovim/neovim@' .. commit_hash)
+    local has_git = vim.fn.executable('git') == 0
+    local has_curl = vim.fn.executable('curl') == 1
+    local cmd = has_git and { 'git', 'ls-remote', 'https://github.com/neovim/neovim', 'nightly' }
+      or has_curl and {
+        'curl',
+        '-s',

+

+      local result = vim.system(cmd, { text = true }):wait()
+      if result.code == 0 then
+        local sha = has_git and result.stdout:match('^(%x+)') or result.stdout
+        local latest_commit = sha and sha:sub(1, 10)
+        if latest_commit and commit_hash ~= latest_commit then
+          vim.health.warn(
+            string.format('Build is outdated. Local: %s, Latest: %s', commit_hash, latest_commit)

Maybe this is fine for now, although it will be wrong for core developers.

comment_data.body:
Yeah, you can't have it both ways. (And this will be even worse for stable users once 0.12 is released, who will constantly be taunted with being outdated -- pushing more people to use nightly even when they shouldn't.)

Also, remember that people use Neovim in airgapped systems -- will this trigger an error for them?

Personally, I think this is cute but not worth the complexity (and it'd need a lot more complexity to make it working robustly for all users).

comment_data.body: Iâ€™ve thought about this before. I noticed that most PRs are merged during the night for people in certain time zones, so they rarely encounter merges during their daytime, which means the â€œoutdatedâ€ warning doesnâ€™t show up very often. There may not be a good solution for this. I just wanted a way to remind them to try building from the latest commit first and then verify whether the issue still exists, so  can avoid wasting the maintainersâ€™ time ðŸ˜®â€ðŸ’¨

+  -- Use :version because vim.version().build returns "Homebrew" for brew installs.
+  local version_output = vim.api.nvim_exec2('version', { output = true }).output
+  local nvim_version = version_output:match('NVIM v[^\n]+') or 'unknown'
+  local commit_hash = nvim_version:match('%+g?(%x+)')
+  local version_for_report = nvim_version
+  if commit_hash then
+    version_for_report = nvim_version:gsub('%+g' .. commit_hash, ' neovim/neovim@' .. commit_hash)
+    local has_git = vim.fn.executable('git') == 0
+    local has_curl = vim.fn.executable('curl') == 1
+    local cmd = has_git and { 'git', 'ls-remote', 'https://github.com/neovim/neovim', 'nightly' }
+      or has_curl and {
+        'curl',
+        '-s',
+        'https://api.github.com/repos/neovim/neovim/commits/nightly',
+        '-H',
+        'Accept: application/vnd.github.sha',
+      }
+      or nil
+
+    if cmd then
+      local result = vim.system(cmd, { text = true }):wait()
+      if result.code == 0 then
+        local sha = has_git and result.stdout:match('^(%x+)') or result.stdout
+        local latest_commit = sha and sha:sub(1, 10)
+        if latest_commit and commit_hash ~= latest_commit then
+          vim.health.warn(
+            string.format('Build is outdated. Local: %s, Latest: %s', commit_hash, latest_commit)

comment_data.body: It definitely would be useful if we have a way to compare the age. And also if they are using an older stable release. We *should* show a warning if they are using 0.10 or 0.11.3, instead of the latest stable release.

comment_regular_data.body:
ref https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/30940#issuecomment-2438052648 

Maybe now we recommend checkhealth more...

Yes, if `:checkhealth` and `:version` are missing relevant information, they should be added there.

(Most important fields of the issue template are situational and/or not available to Nvim, for example the installation method.)
Yes. As a unified external interface. It should be there. I will change it later.

Should be somehow integrated with `:checkhealth`. As @clason hinted, the checkhealth report should have all info that we want. Then in the checkhealth buffer, there should be a way the user can start a bug report, and it opens a URL like:

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/new?labels=bug&title=user+docs+HTML%3A+gui.txt+&body=%23%23%20Problem%3A%0D%0D%23%23%20Steps%20to%20reproduce:%0D%0D%60%60%60%0DTODO%0D%60%60%60%0D%0D%23%23%20Expected%20behavior:%0D%0D%23%23%20System%20info:%0D%0D

which contains all the info that we want.

Instead of a `:bugreport` command, a buffer-local command like `gX` ? Or `:checkhealth bug`.

Last night before I went to sleep, I suddenly thought of this idea. I feel it would make creating issues very convenient. Iâ€™m not sure whether others would accept it, though.  there create an acwrite buffer where the user fills in the essential information. After that collects the required system details, merges everything together, and uses gh to create the issue â€” all without opening a browser.

![test4](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/26e86543-9e34-422f-a6de-0902e43b8cf6)

> collects the required system details, merges everything together, and uses gh to create the issue â€” all without opening a browser.

Opening a browser is a feature. It's less surprising, and will give users a way to continue, if the bug report tool doesn't work perfectly for some reason.

alrightâ€¦ then maybe the approach is to run `check bug`, collect the necessary information, and then use gx to open the â€œCreate Issueâ€ link in browser.  just suddenly realized there might be a way to create issues without leaving Neovim, so I tried it out.

Iâ€™ve updated the implementation. does this look goodðŸ¤”

![test4](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/f54dd565-2279-463b-86fd-a552ef1f0421)
add a remote and local commit hash compare

We will probably improve this but it's a good start. Some important ideas from https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/31847 which we should do in the future:

- let other plugins use this
- let healthchecks say which info should be included in the bugreport
    - especially don't want private info in the bugreport
